text: The CAMERA briskly retreats as FORTY, HIGHLY CHARGED,  ATTRACTIVE, YOUNG PEOPLE march towards it. Each side of t frame is black as this troupe of young actors moves up th middle, everyone talking, grinning, squealing,... everyon having the "high" of their lives.

As the troupe, with geometric precision, spills into a la room (containing a raised dance floor); the CAMERA begins move past dancing couples as a legend appears: 'This is 1975 and Matt Hobbs is singled out for the first time.' And now the CAMERA reveals MATT HOBBS. His open, friendly American face slips between some of the many cracks in hi profession. The face at 26, and forever more, not arresti enough for a leading man; not quirky enough for a "charac Matt must briefly walk on the dance floor to make his way past a knot of people. He dances furiously for two second then steps down as THE DANCERS BEGIN TO SING "WOW", but j as the song breaks out musically, we hear the SOUND OF PE SHHHING; the singers falter and then stop as the party-go gather, in choreographed movement, at a ceiling mounted T set.
We can barely discern the words. . ."with his review is  Leonard Graff." A FRANTIC ACTRESS yelps a command:
I can't hear over this shhing.
Silence, then:
...a play about guess what? That's  right, young people.
He stands next to a ruggedly handsome and extremely nause CONTEMPORARY.
I can't look.
Good idea, let's not.
He begins to walk, the Handsome Contemporary falling into step. Everyone they pass is straining, upwards, at the TV
How can we not listen to this?
We'll know all we need to from the  reaction.

At that moment, the rest of the party-goers turn from the as one, looking mugged. (One girl briefly gets our attent because she is particularly distraught; tears streaming d her angry face. The mixture of tears and rage are, of cou the chemical components of incredible sexiness. Her name BETH.) A TORTURED MALE DANCER offers an incantation.
He should be shot, he should be dead,  he should rot in hell, then come  back as the soap cake in a urinal.
(to dancer) He didn't like it?
The DIRECTOR moves through the group, bucking up spirits.
Don't worry. He doesn't count. We'll  just wait for the papers.

head_text.subj: ON MATT AND FELLOW CAST MEMBERS

text: As they morosely watch the Director approach.
Hey, no matter what this review says,  the play was a great experience for  me.
Beth looks at him, puzzled.
(again) I mean, it is about process, right?
Matt's right. Good Lord, it is what  we're alive for.

Beth turns from the conversation, finding it preposterous then rivets her attention on the Director, walking toward them, holding a ridiculously thick sheaf of papers. Beth  begins to sob in anticipation.
You've just got to be tougher than  this.
(incredulous) Tougher than this?!?
The Director reaches them.
I took it all down over the phone.  It's quite bad. And, unfortunately,  it's very, very long. I've got a  broken heart and writers' cramp.  He...
He's nuts.
He savages everyone.
I don't want to hear anymore. Let's  dance.
Except you, Matt.
They all look at him.
(fiercely to Matt) You filthy bastard.
(drawing closer to  Matt) What did he say?
The Director hunts for the paragraph.
Don't read it.
Oh, please. You can't wait to run  out of here, buy a flashlight, and  then go into some dark alley and  drool over every word.
(truthfully) You're wrong. I'm maybe relieved and  curious. That's it.
(wildly exasperated) What did they say about him?
(reading) ...'in the midst of this delirium of  pretension...'
Don't. This divisive crap won't...

(again) '...one actor, rather miraculously,  manages to provide passion and, yes,  truth. Matt Hobbs, in the supporting  role of Jesus, manages to touch the  heart long after you thought it numbed  by boredom.'
The table of actors look at a sober Matt. A long beat and then, against his will, he grins... then a short, involun barking laugh of joy... then:
(to his colleagues  with sincerity) Sorry.
As we HEAR the next lines of "WOW", BEGIN MAIN TITLES as CAMERA BOOMS UP to the outside of a small apartment as a  legend appears on screen:
Beth, now 27, is standing in front of a TV set showing th Emmy dancers performing a phrase of "WOW". She screams ou
Will you get in here--for God's sake?
Matt, 30, is on the phone.
(into phone) Come on, Ma, how could I show up  tonight when my union is boycotting  the Emmys? Look, I have to hang up.
(screaming voice) It's on right now... right now...  right this second! You will miss  it!!
(into phone) I gotta go. Watch!
Matt hangs up and tear-asses into the living room. Beth  screams as his name is read.
(on TV) ...and Matt Hobbs for 'Caine Mutiny  Court Martial'... And the winner is  Powers Boothe for 'Jonestown--Story  of a Massacre.'
Shit! Fuck! Shit!
He was good.
(again) Shit! Shit! Shit! Fuck! Shit! Look,  he even showed up.
That took courage. I wonder if they  send you something for just being  nominated?
Of all the pathetic questions.
(sharply) Why are you being so damn foul?
Beth glares at him, on the verge of taking him on--but he looking at her very directly... the lack of any other age giving him a temporary edge... Beth decides to state the  unadorned truth.
We've been going back and forth on  our status for so long. I was hoping  that if you won, it might mean  something for us.
Look, Beth... the only...
She is waving her hand in a circle... he is puzzled.
Please go fast. I can't take you  dragging it out.
(a bit faster) The only reason I haven't...
I promised myself I wouldn't be so  bossy. Take your time!! Was that  bossy too?

(persisting) The only thing I have against getting  married is that it might not be fair  because I'm going to stay with acting  forever and you know how erratic the  money's been and there's no resolve...
Do I get to vote? I'm going to tell  you something I never told you before.  Your feeling towards your work is  one of the things I love most about  you.
Really?
Maybe the most.
Hey, then we have no problem here.  Marry me.
They kiss, then break, murmuring to each other.
Stinker, I almost gave up on you.
I was just worried whether I could  make you happy.

A SET FRAME showing several clusters of waiting people. A man rushes to one of these clusters, cueing this group to sing the next phrase of "WOW". As an extremely hyper Matt enters, the SONG STOPS and a legend appears:

(extremely hyper) Everything's okay... Great... She's  six or eight pounds even. Oh, God...  Nothing like it. I'll tell you  something amazing. They really reach  right into her stomach and pull out  this baby. It's not just a rumor.  God. I understand the expression  'mind blowing' for the first time.  It means something so wonderful  happens that the top of your head  comes off and your brain pops out.  Part of it was terrifying, the baby  was turned and they couldn't budge  her. I kept looking at this one woman  doctor's eyes. And when Jeannie  finally came out, this doctor and I  each wiped away a tear at the exact  same time, caught ourselves doing  it, and then laughed together at the  same time. Nothing can prepare you  for it. You know why you're alive.
As Matt walks with pep, accompanied by a burst of "WOW".
Beth holds BABY JEANNIE and wears a scowl.
How you doing? What's wrong?
My mother said you were flirting  with the doctor during the delivery.
On Matt's expression...
Matt and Beth lie on an open sofa-bed. "WOW" is completed though with a dirge-like cadence. We hear a baby crying o a cheap walky-talky near their bed.
Could you get her, honey? I have  that big reading tomorrow.
No, I have a lot to do tomorrow,  too. I have to borrow on our Christmas  Club, I have to...

Don't worry about money anymore. (on her look) I didn't want to tell you, because  it may sound a little strange when I  say it out loud. You know me, I'm  never that cocky. But I'm going to  get 'Spider Woman'. It's me or Raul  and I've never been so sure. It's  weird, but I just know it. I do.
(broadly) Boy, am I reassured. What good news.  Isn't that a load off?
Where we see the crying baby holding the walky-talky in f of its mouth as it screams into the mouthpiece.
I am gonna get this part, Beth.
I can't stand this anymore.
It's an awful place... the start-up apartment he's way to old for... but we don't yet see his humble quarters. Rath
Then, the screen is CLEARED ON ONE HALF so we see half of contact lens holder in focus--the other half blurred--unt Matt gets his second contact in.
A tube of tooth bleach. CLOSE ON THE DIRECTIONS, then:

Bleaching his teeth... finishing... smiling in the mirror This is the bleached smile of fear--true fear--the awful  state of having lost your way. The phone rings. Matt clea his voice before answering.
(into phone) Hello... Hi, Beth. I'm glad you  finally returned my call. What are  you so mad about? (again, into phone) YOU KNOW, YOU'RE NOT THE ONLY ONE  WHO CAN SCREAM, I CAN SCREAM, TOO.
Matt was so suddenly, emotionally extended that the anger leaves him that quickly... just a strange atypical lightn bolt of rage toward life and women.

(again, into phone) You know what? I'm being a sort of  gutless wonder here. I'm yelling  back at you because I'm embarrassed.  I won't be able to take the kid when  I said... Why don't you listen for a  second?
He rubs his head with both hands, including the one holdi the phone. This allows us to hear his ex-wife repeat the  same sentence over and over again.
(from phone) ...You're taking her... You're taking  her... You're taking her...

Beth, I know exactly how long it's  been and I feel strange as hell not  seeing her but this isn't a choice.  I'm broke. It's the driest spell of  my life. I'm not saying it's your  problem, but it's no place for a six- year-old. What can I do? The only  full-time job I seem to have is not  showing how scared I am. What? No,  that's not something I said before. (accepting compliment) Well, thanks.
Beth turns angry again. Matt finds, unfortunately, that h got one more act of bravado left.
(again, into phone) Beth, Hey... hey. Never mind, I'll  do it.
He hangs up.
(again, to himself) I must get work. I will take anything.  I must get work. I must not be  embarrassed by these pep talks to  myself...

As Matt walks from the outdoor parking lot, past inexpens homes. In the lot, on private lawns and every public benc at each street corner, are various actors doing the relax exercises which will form the basis of A DANCE, as they g over their "sides".
...feathers I'm blowing. What am I,  a duck?
We pass various actors going over alternate sentences for the same speech so that we get a sense of the speech as a whole from the sum of its parts.

1) I'm not thinking about whether  I'm going to shoot you. I'm... 2)...trying to decide where. 3)...the little spot behind the ear  where you die before you hear the  shot... 4)...on the left side of the belly  which is a very mean place.

An office building of clear architectural merit located i an industrial area. Even the sign "Popcorn Pictures" has the artistic dignity the name itself lacks... MUSIC ENTER Gradually, movement BECOMES CHOREOGRAPHED...i.e., the you actor and actress running across the street do so with  uncommon grace. The area Matt passes is very crowded and still haven't reached the most congested area of all as w STUDY FACES and HEAR snatches of the actors' preparation.
What am I, a duck?
Sure I'll tell you... Favor first...  Do a nice middle-aged lady a favor...  A fair trade... tell you what you  want to know in return for a... (grimaces over dialogue  she must say) ...a pity fu...
MUSIC BECOMING MORE INSISTENT as we approach the building the mumbling of the actors taking on the SOUND of a Waili Wall...

...the height of ego. You think your  he-manness can make me get on that  elevator even though I'm phobic?...  I CAN'T GET ON THAT ELEVATOR. I don't  care if... they catch us. DO YOU  GET... IT. DO YOU GET IT! I CAN'T! I  CAN'T... three, please.
SINGING the dialogue...
...can't get on the elevator... can't  get on the elevator... even if you  make me... even if you make me. Do  you get it?... do you get it?...

Standing near each other--exchange glares as they break e other's concentration and move apart... THEIR MOVEMENT SE as our gateway to DANCING... The SONG "MAKE BELIEVE" ente fully now and builds in intensity, reaching a repeated ph as we move to Matt and he enters the building, thereby cu off the song.
As the SONG continues in intensity, Matt enters the build at the end of a repeated phrase cutting off the song as w move to:

Where CATHY BRESLOW, age 30, waits. Hollywood is a bit of uphill struggle for Cathy. She is bright where others are brilliant, pretty where others are gorgeous, enormously h working where others are obsessive-compulsive. She is cle waiting for someone while reading an enormously thick boo galley. Matt almost scoots by her, then stops.
Hi... See, I did recognize you. You  didn't have to wait for me.
Well, I wanted to introduce you. As  if knowing me would help.
MOVING SHOT. Staircase packed with actors, an uphill slal almost impossible to navigate.
It's a ridiculously awful movie.
Well, challenge. I wasn't sure you'd  remember me... let alone help...
Stop. You're good. I'm doing them a  favor by getting you in.
Well, that's a fresh slant.
They reach the casting assistant, CLAIRE.
Claire, this is Matt Hobbs.

As Matt is handed a set of sides, we SHOOT PAST Matt as h watches Cathy move back down the stairs before he can say another word. She moves with wit. He is struck by her. He looks back at Claire, who has an intricate hairdo and a r smile.
Hi. Sorry. We're running behind...  Please forgive us.
Her hairdo wilted, her blouse soiled, her smile gone, the tendons of her neck prominent.
(fiercely) Matt Hobbs? Matt Hobbs!
Going over his lines. Hearing his name, he rises. Claire  gestures him in.
The walls are pockmarked with movie posters. THREE MEN si in an area some distance from the desk. The casting direc MARTIN, makes the introduction:
This is Matt Hobbs... This is John  Earl McAlpine, the director.
Good to see you.
He speaks with an Australian accent, gets half-up and ext his hand.
...and Burke Adler, the producer.
So, what have you been doing with  yourself... (checking resume) ...the last few years?
(to Burke) I'm real bad at interviews, so, if  you don't mind, I'd really prefer to  just read first.
That's the way you want to do it?
Yes.
Maybe we shouldn't even read. I'll  just take your word that you're good.
Matt smiles.

No. I'm serious. There's all different  ways. Did you know Woody Allen never  reads actors? He just looks at them,  feels around a little and then decides  who he wants. That's his way. Doesn't  hear them do a line. I also have a  way. What I do is interview first-- then read--maybe do it all over again  the next day. I call up people the  actor has worked with--check him  out. If he's famous, I do an opinion  survey to test how much people like  him. If he's not famous, I put him  on tape and show it to everyone I  can grab. I believe in screen tests;  I believe in replacing if the dailies  are bad, in cutting people out if  the previews aren't there. Because  I'm not doing movies for theaters  where they serve cappucino in the  lobby. I'm doing popcorn movies. You  want to know what I like? Come to my  house, look at my lamps... you won't  find it in my movies. In my movies,  you'll find out what I know. I know  how to do detail. What I don't know,  I discover. Yesterday we finished  mixing a movie--the last scene is in  a field of windmills which blows up  and all the blades of these windmills  slice through the air, one of which  hits a four-story tank of propane  gas. A humongous explosion scene. I  kept on saying 'louder', and they  finally said to me they couldn't go  louder without distortion. We went  louder. We had to discover a thing,  a filter, but we went louder. I don't  question doing these things. I do  them. So if you want to know if it's  okay to do it differently--not to  talk--to just read first... I say... (pointing to John  Earl) Ask him--he's the director.
Whatever.
Okay, let's do it. Do you have any  questions?
They only gave me these two pages.  I'd like to give this my best shot.  So if I could read the script and  come back...
This part works tomorrow.
Oh. Who will I be reading with?
Burke indicates Martin.
(from his chair) Can I read from here?
I want you to do it wherever you're  comfortable, but I'd prefer it if  you were comfortable standing up.
Matt rises uncomfortably. A SECRETARY enters and hands a  note to the director.
Time for my buns to have visitors.
Matt looks astonished as the director leaves the room.
(to Matt) Go ahead.
Go ahead? The director left.
That's okay, he trusts me, uh... And  we're just doing the first page.
(cueing him badly) 'Okay, darling Harry, here it is...  If someone were breaking up with me,  I'd like it short and sweet. What  about you?'
(reading--showing  pain) 'Incredibly drawn out...'
'I can't take care of you right now.  What am I, your mother?'
(intense) 'Well, what am I? Your duck?'
As he gets into the scene he begins to experience some re of the desperate feelings he's been harboring.
(again) 'We've been together two years and  you act like all you're doing is  blowing away some feathers. So what  I'm asking...'
You didn't do the quack.
Huh?
The stage direction says for him to  quack.
I know, but why would he quack when  someone's breaking up with him?
Hopefully because it's funny.
This isn't a comedy.
Then we're in trouble, because they're  already fall down laughing at the  teaser-trailer in fifty-two hundred  and thirty theaters.
A comedy? (rubbing his face) I think I have to make an adjustment  here.

We HEAR the strains of the theme of a past hit movie comi from Cathy's cassette player. A rack of soundtracks clear visible. Cathy is frowning as she reads the last of the g pages. She overhears some conversation in the adjoining r which begins to disturb her concentration.
I'm not supposed to read TV pilots.  Don't call us D-Girls. We're  Development Persons!

Cathy closes the door, shutting her off. She now begins t fill out a form with a felt-tipped pen. As she does so, t pad is supered on the screen--action seen through it. As writes, we see the notations on the super. It is marked COVERAGE--CONFIDENTIAL FROM: CATHY BRESLOW. BURKE ADLER. SUBJECT: (the pen writes out) "LITTLE DICK"  GENRE/CATEGORY (the pen writes out ACTION-ADVENTURE). The there are columns to check EXCELLENT, GOOD, FAIR, POOR fo the story. CHARACTERS, DIALOGUE... The pen checks FAIR fo story, POOR for all else, CHARACTER, DIALOGUE, etc. The f then states--CHECK ONE OF THE FOLLOWING SENTENCES:

head_text.subj: I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PROJECT
I'D STAKE MY ALL ON THIS PROJECT
I'D GLADLY STAKE MY ALL ON THIS PROJECT

text: The phone rings. As she picks it up and reaches to turn d the volume of the motion picture soundtrack she's listeni to.

(into phone) Hi. I just finished. I'll have my  coverage right over. It's past  derivative... it's photocopying.  What a hoot! You're kidding, right?  There is truly active bidding for  this book? Really? 2.3 million? Okay,  see you.
She hangs up and begins to alter the form changing the  STORY/POOR to STORY/EXCELLENT, and all the other POORS to GOOD... and now the Recommend section.
The pen is poised.

Her soul is poised. A beat and she allows "I DO NOT RECOM to stand, the source music theme--"CHARIOTS OF FIRE"-- coincidentally celebrates this considerable act of herois Cathy takes the sheet and walks to the door.
As she approaches her secretary's desk, she overhears two other members of Burke's Development Staff (a 27-year-old well-dressed man and a woman younger than Cathy) as they  enthuse.
Even the title "Little Dick"--it  means so many things.
Story, story, story, story, story. (seeing Cathy) You loved it, right?
I had some problems.
Like what?
Well, you know, it's a little  garbagey.
So it has to be cast right.
If Cathy doesn't like it, we know  it's a smash.
(stung) Hey. It's not like I didn't recommend  it.
She surreptitiously changes her "recommend" as Matt enter She looks up.
How'd it go?
I didn't get it. He did say something  about wanting me back.
Good. His saver is he means what he  says.
Yeah, I just wanted to say thanks.
She nods and starts to turn back towards her office.
...and I wanted to ask you out.
The other people in the office stare at Matt.
(turns) For when?
Any time.
I never know when I'm free. (Matt nods) It sounds like I'm just... but it's  true.
Okay. Thanks again. I felt funny  asking.
Well, don't please.
I meant asking you to get me the  audition.
Oh... well, don't please.
He nods and starts to go. She looks at him.
Don't be sad.
Matt smiles in astonishment and exits.
Who is he?
Oh, I was auditing this acting course  and he filled in teaching one night.  He did a scene himself and he was  awesome. For some reason, he can't  get arrested.
Yeah. He does seem to have a layer  of loser dust on him.
Matt drives his faded, seven-year-old car into view.
He looks off... sees something that arrests his interest pulls to the curb. It's a curious sight.

Burke Adler, standing at a street corner, palpably in pai He's trying to rein in his emotions, sucking in huge gulp of air... and, then, a wave of emotion gets the better of him as he looks at his watch. A sob escapes him--shocked  that he's so close to tears on a public street corner, he battles for control... another sob as he looks to the hea
A split second to consider, then he's out of his car.

A flow of PEOPLE--in the foreground, the tortured figure Burke Adler--in the background, Matt Hobbs, pauses before intruding. But Burke's spectacle is growing more public,  sounds of anguish escape him.
Oh, God... why? Why?... (louder) What am I going to do?
And now he begins to dissassemble, openly crying--on the  verge of a complete breakdown. Matt moves into frame, gra Burke, trying to provide him with an anchor.
His face--his eyes providing a beacon of strength.
Hey. Hey! HEY!!
Totally fucked-up, wild-eyed. As he witnesses his own sta
Look at me. You'd think I was a  writer. (his story of travail  pours from him) I hired this kid as a production  assistant. His father's a business  manager... a few good clients.
What happened?
He's been driving for me two weeks...  all he has to do is pick me up on  time... he's twenty minutes late and  I have a test screening in the valley.  Everybody's gone from the office.
Burke flails at himself as Matt looks at him.
Is that it? You need a lift?
Yeah.
I'm right over here.
Matt starts to lead him back, then realizes he's alone, B having seen his car finally arrive.
Burke, berating the YOUNG DRIVER. Matt pauses, awed by th wild gesticulating--the few screamed words...
...Not just today... believe me,  there's no way you'll ever make it...  You are going to fail. Listen, listen-- I know about this; you are going to  be a failure.
As he joins Burke and the young man, Burke turns to Matt.
(to Matt) Let's get moving; you said you'd  give me a lift.
What the hell are you talking about?  Not in your car... I've got my own.
I'll give you a hundred and twenty  dollars to take me... and it will  still be a favor. (to Young Man) Get out. Come on. (to Matt) Please. This is very important.
The driver gets out.
(final plea) A guy got shot on the freeway...  Traffic's tied up.
You should leave time for that kind  of thing.
What do you need me for? Don't you  drive?
(a mumble) Yeah, I drive. I don't like to look  for parking.
The sun setting on a nondescript slab of California.

The two men... Matt feeling very peculiar in this line of work. Burke's tension renders him arresting, handsome eve The look of generals who go forth against long odds. He t an enormous cleansing breath. It startles Matt.

(explaining) Yoga shit. I feel like barbed wire.  I don't know if you keep track, but  I'm the sixth independent producer  ever to have two big pictures  scheduled for Christmas, and tonight  we're testing the first one for the  first time... You get it?
Yeah. It's important to you.
(laughing at the  understatement) Yes. I don't think I would have put  it that way... but, yes...
Burke's car moves toward the movie complex.

Our first view of NAN MULHANNEY; middle-aged and pragmati yet extraordinarily naive. She's a scientist of sorts-- monitoring the tastes and feelings of Americans, first in Washington and now here. Though she just had a very rough hour or so, she bends down to smile at Burke.
Keep driving. She runs the test  screenings. Very smart. Very. She  has a real case on me, but so far  I've been keeping it in the bank.
He stops talking, stops breathing, as he sees.

The line consists of disparate, disinterested people who focused on their own small, personal dramas--not at all  cognizant of the fact that they hold a life in their hand They are clearly growing impatient.
Go very slow.
MUSIC IN... Burke steels himself and exits the car.
We're 34 minutes late. The studio is  appropriately wild... people are  beginning to leave... but I knew how  upset you'd be if we started without  you.
(distantly) Yeah. Thanks.
But he pays her no mind as MUSIC CONTINUES and he moves  towards the line. Nan approaches the car.
How is he tonight?
I don't know him, so I have nothing  to compare it to.
Well, how would you say he is, anyway?
Not quite himself.
As he approaches the line, he BEGINS TO SING his love to  them, "I'll Do Anything." As he pours out his misdirected heart to individuals on the line who DO NOT HEAR HIM.

Their impatience gives rise to a VERY SLOW TAP DANCE, eac couple or cluster doing it differently--barely exaggerati the normal shifting of a line... As BURKE CONTINUES TO SI the song builds as does the dance... Burke sings even mor passionately, his D-PEOPLE perhaps joining in as BACKGROU SINGERS. At a key point, the disparate groups turn and fo a SOLID UNIFIED LINE. They begin the rhythmic clapping of impatience--having become a line, they now threaten to be a mob. Burke sings one more Joe Cocker-like passionate pl before turning to camera to shout over the mayhem:
Let them in.
As they enter.
Nan is addressing the audience from down front.

The name of the picture you'll be  seeing is 'Ground Zero'... There may  be some scratches... some of the  colors may be off, there are no final  titles, and it has not been finally  mixed for sound, and the music is  temp, that means temporary...
As she says this:
Where Burke spies the STUDIO HEAD and leaves Matt's side.
As BURKE enters the frame behind him. He is right behind boss' ear. He leans in and offers an intimacy.
I'm glad you came yourself instead  of sending your staff.
The boss is startled--jumps. BURKE eyes him... there must some way to profit from these stolen moments with a power man.
I wouldn't be surprised if tonight's  screening is a monster. (emphatically) Could happen, right?
Sure.
Okay.
He moves back to Matt and Nan at the rear of the audience
(to Matt) Eisner just said he thinks the  screening will be a monster.
Strangely, Burke seems truly buoyed by the words of  encouragement he himself manufactured. He moves down thre rows and sits in an aisle seat just as the film opens wit series of violent explosions.
Please, God, let tonight give him  peace.
Incredibly, Burke turns and gestures to her that the soun of her small voice is interfering with the cacophony of h movie. Nan is clearly stricken by her lapse as she whispe to Matt.
We're short two card-counters, can  you two help out?
We are seeing one of the final moments of the film.

As the muscular hero moves with stealth through the giant refrigerated meat door. He passes cows and dead men hangi from alternate hooks. Suddenly, he is attacked by the vil brandishing an electric meat dismembering tool. The hero  ducks, the machine ripping apart hanging cow flesh. The h grabs the only weapon he can find: a large piece of meat a large bone, which he uses as a mace. He clubs the other man--then again--and again. Part of the audience is whoop and applauding.
Standing with Matt and Cathy. At the sound of the applaus Nan grins and mumbles with a connoisseur's knowledge.
Males, fifteen and under.
Where the hero stands over the man whose face he has  shattered, holding a club from which hang strings of meat He is breathing heavily, and between breaths, states:
Sorry to bust your chops.
General audience laughter.
If you'll just stay in your seats a  few moments and fill out these cards  for us...
Matt and others handing out cards with pencils attached.. Folks filling them out. As an ADOLESCENT MALE fills it ou PREVIEW CARD FILLS THE SCREEN as we view LIVE ACTION THRO IT.
An office meant for two, containing twenty counters. The  counting is done with erasers rifling stacks, creating a  sound, a MUSICAL RHYTHM, as the GROUP CAPTAIN calls out w gospel cadence.
Who has young males? Young women?  Older males?... Older males?...
Matt, his tally finished, squats on the floor, waiting. T Group Captain approaches.
Older males... older males?
Matt looks blank.
(again) Older males... over 25?
Matt now realizes that it is his category and hands over older male cards and exits.
Burke, prowling the lobby as audience stragglers leave an Studio Execs and Popcorn Development Staff wait. He looks off to see Matt and Nan chatting in another part of the l
As they arrive... Nan looks off to see the Group Captain  approach.
How long since you've seen your  daughter?
A little over two years. (on her look) My wife insisted on moving back to  the Midwest--then I was in the  Philippines on the mini-series and...

(suddenly and loudly) Oh, please. It's one thing being a  son-of-a-bitch, but you don't have  to be a stupid son-of-a-bitch. People  move heaven and earth to see their  kids. I don't care if she moved to  Pluto, it's abandonment.
(a pause, then) Hey, we just met.
(realizing) Oh. Sorry.
Make a guess how we did.
It wouldn't mean anything.
Nothing good that happens can make  it worth feeling the way I do now.  Nothing.
An OLDER WOMAN approaches them.
Excuse me.
Who the hell are you? This is private.
I'm Mr. Eisner's mother.
Oh. Can I get you some water?
No, thank you.
The Group Captain approaches and hands Nan a sheet.
Everyone, all the studio and Popcorn staff, is drawn to N
As she glances at the figures.
As she secretly reaches for and holds Burke's hand. Is it sympathy or congratulations?

As we see in ever-so-SLOWED ACTIONS, tense lips turning  gloriously upward to reveal gums--then a smile. More smil as we pan across teeth... bonded executives and bonded te The shot widens. The studio head mumbles to himself as he carefully goes over the tally in every category. Then:
I don't need the numbers. I loved  it.
His smiling face takes us:
Burke, ninety in the top two boxes.
A tear in his eye--a smile shyer than others. He turns to the old lady, instinctively using this victory to settle most recent score as he says mockingly:
Now can I get you some water?

Cathy and Matt are leaning against Burke's car. Cathy is  distraught--temporarily, but horribly, unsure of herself. Matt is looking at her. If he had a little more confidenc going for him right now, he would make his move. But, for now, they are two self-doubters on different trips.
I never thought it would do this  well. There were so many holes; I  told everybody it wasn't going to do  business. Why am I so public with my  opinions?
You might be right.
Not with that score. You know, maybe  tonight's the night I'm losing my  entire mind, but weren't you in  'Platoon?'
Incredible. I was only there for a  minute in the rape scene, moving  past Charlie Sheen when I left the  hut... I had a great scene cut out...  I was...
But there was that one long close up-- where you seemed ashamed of yourself  but still arrogant.
That's exactly what I was going for.
It reminded me of my last boyfriend. (indicating book bag) Got to go.
She hefts the bag--puts it back down--crosses her eyes,  burlesquing the weight of the bag. He helps her put it on her shoulder.
You have to read all that?
Beast of burden.
(sincerely) So what are you, totally wonderful  or what?
She smiles and is gone, staggering a bit under the weight her scripts. Matt looks after her. Burke and Nan approach
How come you haven't said anything?  This is great, right?
No.
What no?
The definite recommends are way off  for a score this high and, even for  action-adventure, it's just too low  for women. (Burke looks anguished) I'm sorry.
He leans against the car for support.
It was such a good score.

(extraordinarily  sympathetic) I know... And, unfortunately,  yesterday's tracking wasn't... (he reacts) I'm sorry... They just don't seem in  the mood for action-adventure right... (he reacts) Sorry... May I tell you one more  thing? (he looks up in  anticipatory fear) I think it's so wonderful that you  don't worry about even trying to act  strong.
Thanks. You want to eat something  sometime?
I'm, uh... I'm blushing from head to  foot.
Good. I'll call you.
As Burke moves to his car. He SEES the Group Captain payi Matt.
Thirty-two, thirty-three.
Burke is looking at Matt with some surprise.
You want to do this regularly for  me? I was gonna offer, but I thought  it would humiliate you.
(straight at him) I don't mind an occasional odd job.  But I can't work tomorrow. I have to  get my kid.
As they get in the car, Burke has the front door open, ab to get in--reconsiders, and gets in the rear door.
Okay, I got the cards to look at--I  think I'll ride back here. (to Nan) Maybe I'll drop by your place  tomorrow.
Matt gets behind the wheel, thereby ending the day as a f fledged chauffeur. They drive off.
Burke and Nan returning from lunch.
So, thanks for lunch. I hope this  leads to an evening date. Though I  have to stay home with my daughter,  Leslie, on Saturdays.
(sincerely) Yeah, okay. You were very interesting  to talk to. I swear to God. Honest.  No kidding. You really were.
I believe you. (sincerely) And I was very surprised what you  were like when you weren't working.  There was absolutely no difference.  You want to see where we do the  tracking?
(excited) Is it okay?
The enter the room containing a maze of telephone cubbies with workers manning the phones.
Nobody ever wants to see how we do  the polling, but they're like little  starved puppies when the data comes  in--running at you, scrambling to...
Burke hardly hears. He is awed as if by a cathedral.
1) How often do you go to the movies? 2) I'm going to describe a movie in  one sentence and then ask you to  rate it on a scale of...
(as the workers  continue) I love this. This is what counts and  this is where you count it.
(soft and true) That's the same way I feel.
You phone all over--you know what  movies they're waiting to see, whether  your TV spots are working. You know  what the country thinks.
...what feelings do you have about  Cher as a singer, an actress, or  potential date...
(again) ...and it's accurate.
Within six-point-eight percent.
And you can't fix it... right?
No... no... Sometimes just for myself,  I can't resist asking America a  personal question.
Like?
(simply) When do you feel more worthless-- mornings or afternoons?
I gotta get back.
They pause by a workers to say goodbye.
Assume Michelle Pfeiffer is the woman-- which of these 67 actors would you  most like to see her with... Patrick  Swayze, Keanu Reeves, Dustin Hoffman,  Johnny Dep, the guy from 'Major  Dad'...
There's something I meant to tell  you. You may have noticed something  unusual about me.
I gotta get back.
I could never find the right time  to...
Is this urgent?
Well, maybe not urgent, but  immediately significant and necessary  to tell. (a deep breath) You see, there's these pills...
'Cause I gotta go. I'm listening  with an eighth of an ear now.
So long.
He exits as the telephone pollster continues with the lis of prospective Michelle Pfeiffer male co-stars.
Matt, wearing earphones, is in the middle of a row of fiv intent on what he is watching.
A recent example of a great actor in a regular movie...  something like Brando in "The Freshman." No sound.

Watching intently. Not watching--studying... not studying fully appreciating. Now he sees a particularly good momen looks around joyously for half a beat--a reflex to share  what he saw. His neighbors, not quite knowing what he's  smiling at; he returns his attention to the screen.
As Matt's cab pulls up. He opens the front gate and walks to the porch, noting a tricycle, stirred by old guilts. H knocks on the door. A MAN answers.
Are you Matt?
Uh-huh.
I didn't know if we could wait much  longer. Come on in.
He lights a cigarette, takes three quick drags, then flic it away before walking inside behind Matt.
(again) She's a real nut on smoking anywhere  near the kid.

They enter. A bedroom down a narrow hallway from where th stand. Remember "The Best Years of Our Lives"... Frederic March coming home from the wars and seeing his wife just beat before she sees him. Here we have a wretched mutant that moment. Beth, still fierce and attractive, is packin her daughter's suitcase when she senses him and looks up. Shaking her head with a disapproval which will never die, she walks to him.
Hello--did you two meet?
Not really. Is she ready? I have the  taxi waiting.
I just have to say goodbye. You have  no idea how difficult that is.
It's three weeks.
It's not three weeks.
Yes, it is.
No, it's not.
Several beats--Beth and the man staring at Matt.
It is.
He doesn't know?
You are not taking her for a visit.  You are taking her for a while.
Just because you want to go off with  him doesn't mean I...
You're getting the wrong idea.
I don't think so. No matter how you  put this...
Hey, look, I'm a United States  Marshal. I'm here because she didn't  show up yesterday to start serving  her time.
I don't have a choice. You don't  have a choice.
She turns and starts for the other room.
What did she do?
(turning) I loved, helped and supported in  every possible way a business man  who committed the terrible crime of  being financially imaginative with a  pension fund.
She exits. He sits down, stunned in the headlights of his fate.

Matt and the Marshal in the foreground as Beth talks to  Jeannie in the background. We see only glimpses of them.  Beth's face as she leans towards Jeannie from one side of the doorway--just Jeannie's legs dangling on the other si
Okay, listen carefully, Jeannie. Be  still. Now, what's the most important  thing in life to know?
No one will ever love me as much as  you do.
Matt and the Marshal exchange a look of mutual horror.
Good. Now, concentrate with all your  muscles and remember everything I'm  about to say to you...
The Marshal and Matt shift uncomfortably.
Don't talk to strangers. They may be  killers. Take your vitamins so the  poison in the food can't hurt you.  What else now?
Teeth.
Right. Thank you. Brush right after  you eat or your gums will start to  bleed in your sleep and choke you.
The Marshal and Matt can stand no more--they each call to her... "Beth... Beth... Mrs. Hobbs... Beth." She looks ou and then walks to them.
What? I'm giving Jeannie her  reminders.
Reminders?!? You can't say things  like that to a little...
No. Don't. No. Don't dare. Don't  criticize the way I mother or I think  I'll start to scream and never st...
Mrs. Hobbs.
(suddenly cheery) Yes.
You know, I've been involved with  this sort of thing for a long time.

You're not going to criticize me,  are you? Not in front of him--because  all he's done is send Jeannie these  long, stupid letters. He doesn't  even realize she can't read. He sends  letters to someone who can't read. (laughs) It's almost funny.
I thought you'd read them to her.
(realizing) Oh.

I'm not faulting you. You love your  daughter and this is a very tough  thing to go through. You feel guilty  and caring and it all gets mixed up  so that there's so much important  stuff going down that there's no  sure way of dealing with it, but the  best thing you can do is just make  sure you love her.
Typical cop talk. (on his look) But I understand what you're trying  to say. Thank you. Can I have another  minute with her?

She returns to the doorway which still only provides us w glimpses as she SINGS, "DON'T TALK TO STRANGERS." The CAM MOVES down the hallway to INTRODUCE JEANNIE, trying to pu things out as she sits amongst a ridiculous number of  suitcases.
As the two females who bear his name approach. Matt doesn want a pregnant first moment with Jeannie, so he wards of silence with chatter. Unfortunately, he can only think of one word.
Hi, hi, hi, hi, hi, hi.
(laughing mirthlessly) Hello, monster-poop.
(to U.S. Marshal) She has her mother's sense of humor.
Beth stops him with a look, then bends down.
Okay, love, Mommy's going to help  others who need her for a few years,  and you're going with Daddy as I  explained. (to Marshal and Matt) We'll all have to help with the  luggage.
All three adults and Jeannie sharing the burden of the lu as they move towards the cab. Mother and child hug. Matt  struck by his child's plight, him.

(turning to Matt) Beginning now, you must give less  value to your own happiness and well- being, then hopefully, you will reach  the point where you give that no  value whatsoever. Give her everything.  There's no such thing as spoiling a  child.
Even if you have to steal to do it?
You don't really want to mess with  me, do you?
(simple honesty) No.
(to Jeannie) Okay, sweetie. We have to go.
(to Beth) I want to go with you.
Can't, pretty-heart. I'm sorry.
Tears fall from Jeannie's eyes.
Not even a compromise?
(thinking) The compromise will be that you don't  have to ride in back; you can ride  up front with the driver... okay?
What?
Okay.
As Beth buckles Jeannie into the front seat, Matt gets in the back, alone, feeling preposterous. Beth nods to the  Marshal, who surreptitiously handcuffs her.
(to driver) Can we please go?
The cab pulls away. Matt leans towards her as she looks b at the receding figure of her mother and grows still.
As she sings him one last line of "DON'T TALK TO STRANGER
Matt checks Jeannie's luggage, then takes her hand. She l him. He is grateful.
It's going to be okay. I'm you're  dad, you know? So it will be okay.  You and I will make it okay. You  ever ridden in a plane before?
(a sudden gust of  anger) Yesssss!
Jeannie and Matt in the center two seats of a five seat r Jeannie is coloring in a book which Matt bought her; he i holding some extra crayons.
Don't stare at me.
Sorry.
I want to put on my yellow dress  now.
It's underneath the plane. We can't  get it.
And just that quick, Jeannie screams.
I want to put on my dress. I want to  put on my dress.
Other passengers turn around. This is pretty raw stuff we into. Temper in all its wildness, MUSIC UNDER... electric guitar beginning to match the energy and naked emotion of the child.
There's no way we can get the dress-- it's impossible.
Jeannie's feet start kicking in front of her--the person that seat turning sharply around.
Don't kick the seat!
I want the yellow dress. (a shriek) Give me a compromise.
She is crying now.
As soon as we land. That's the  compromise.
Without warning, Jeannie slaps herself in the face. All f people in the row ahead turn and say in unison:
Don't hit her.
God, I didn't hit her--she hit her.
As everyone starts pushing the cabin attendant call butto These dings magnify until they're part of the music--as i drives and drives... Matt takes Jeannie's hand and tries restrain her.
Noooooo. Let go of me. Noooo. The  yellow dress... let go... let go.
She breaks away from him. He moves after her.
At breakneck speed, Jeannie dashes through the plane with her father in pursuit... flashes of disapproving faces. T seat belt sign goes on. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT blocks his pat
You'll have to sit down.
Jeannie takes advantage of Matt's being stopped and moves into the toilet, locking the door behind her.
(yelling) Jeannie, we have to sit down. Please.
We'll be having some turbulence for  the next twenty minutes or so. Will  the cabin attendants please take  their seats?
Sir.
(simply and utterly) I have no idea what to do.
A sudden bump and Matt falls. He yells to the locked door
Jeannie, you okay?
Go back to your seat. I'll get her.

As Matt makes his way back, the Flight Attendant uses a h latch to open the door. Music building--then calming, the worst is over. Matt makes his way back to his seat, shell shocked. The Attendant leans over him.
She wants to be alone. So we're  upgrading her.
He just nods.
Down the aisle--Jeannie lets an Attendant lead her as she peers back at her dad.
Matt carrying the sleeping child like a sack over his  shoulder, also managing to hold onto all her luggage.
He has propped her on the sofa, a cotton nightgown out. H is unbuttoning her dress. She opens her eyes, the window' protective bars PLACING A SHADOW ACROSS HER FACE. She att to cover her fear.
These are the wrong jammies.
Okay... so what do we do?
Jeannie mimics him perfectly under her breath. She goes t an open suitcase and throws things on the floor until she finds the right jammies.
Where do I sleep?
I have a sleeping bag and bed. Which  one do you want?
She surveys her pitiful choice; then points to the sleepi bag.
That.
She gets into it. He zips her up--then she says something remarkably unexpected.
Hug.
Amazed, Matt hugs her. A half-beat, then:
(sharply) Let go.
He does--then stands and looks down at her. She looks bac mocking his stare with one of her own.

Nan uncertainly enters this decidedly masculine bathroom. She is wearing an evening gown. The sun streams through t lush foliage outside a wall-sized window. MUSIC as she op her purse and removes a pillbox; at one point lightly sin a snatch of lyric concerning the conflicts of being a sin woman and a single mother--this while totally focused on pills.
A major movie shot of this compartmentalized box. Each  burrowed nest clearly labeled for the pill it contains:

head_text.subj: VITAMIN B, VITAMIN A, OSCILLOCOCCINUM, PROZAC, CALCIUM, T

text: MUSIC CONTINUES. She dials a phone number while arching h neck and swallowing one pill after another with little sw of water. This process continuing, even as she speaks int the phone.

Monica--is Leslie up yet? Good. I  didn't want you to get worried when  you realized I wasn't there. I'm  still with that man. I'll tell you  about it later. But it's sure nice  to have wobbly legs again. Look,  today's recycling day for Leslie at  school, so give her some empty cans...  well, then dump some out for her!  Tell her I had to leave real early  for work and I'll pick her up at  school myself to make up for it and  we'll rent any cassette she wants  for tonight. Thank you... Take good  care.
She hangs up. Another snatch of lyric as she bends to bru her teeth with her finger; prepares herself and opens the door to greet her new lover.
Burke sits on the edge of the bed, fearful. He sees her.
Oh, I thought you took off in the  middle of the night.
She moves quickly to him.
No. I just had to call home. Is that  why you're sad?
No. It's Everett. This kid who used  to work for me. He was always crazy  to do his own movie.
(fearing worst) What happened?
(very down) His movie not only opened to a three  million dollar Friday--it's gotten  great reviews.

Nan is dumbfounded; still she puts a hand on him, actuall consoling him for his hideous thought--Hollywood lovers: wrapped up with ill thoughts of others; she, feeling inti yet severely compromised. Cupid's work is done.
(again) Listen. I'm tremendously worried  about 'Ground Zero' because of the  bad 'want to sees' you sent over.  But that's just me being nervous  over nothing, isn't it?
No. That's just you correctly  assessing the situation. So stop  being so hard on yourself.
He eyes her, then:

We hear a muffled argument between Matt and Jeannie comin from inside their apartment. Then the door opens and Matt holding Jeannie by the hand, moves down the hall to the n door and knocks. (NOTE: Jeannie is dressed in layers of v clothing--some of the layers play clothes, some fit for a coronation. She is a pocket contemporary Annie Hall... he style so much her own it transcends judgement. Her hair i unkempt. The door opens revealing Lucy, an Hispanic woman her mid-30s.
How're you doing? I'm from next door.  I see you with your kids in the  laundry room...
Hello. (seeing Jeannie, turns  warmer) ...Who are you?
Jeannie is a bit shy.
Say, 'Hello, I'm your new neighbor  now too.'
Jeannie says nothing.
I'm Lucy Crisala... What's your name?
Jeannie says nothing.
Say, 'Jeannie.'
The form of the conversation is forged. Jeannie not answe anything. Matt bending over to Jeannie while he forms her answers to Lucy.
I have a little girl too.
Say, 'Isn't that nice... How old is  she?'
She's four and a half and I have a  little boy who is not yet one year.
Say, 'That's nice... I'd like to  play with them... My Daddy didn't  know your phone number, so we just  decided to...'
(interrupting) What can I do for you?

Say 'Daddy has to go to work tonight  and...' (catching himself and  looks directly at  Lucy) I need someone to help me and her on  short notice. I've seen your around  with your kids and hoped you knew  someone in the building or close by.  I've got this new job that starts  now. Do you know anyone?
Well, I'm always here. I could maybe  do it myself.
(there is a God and a  good one at that) Oh, this is so great. Let's work out  a full-time schedule and...
Wait. Jeannie, why don't you come in  for a minute and meet Ricky and Essa.  Come on, we're making fruit bars.
Jeannie walks into the apartment past her father.
(again, to Matt) Why don't you leave her for a while  and then we talk.
Sort of a test?
We'll just see how it works.

Play-pen in the middle of the floor... Jeannie stands the staring at Essa who is playing with her little brother. M moves to embrace Jeannie who cranes away from him. He sta with it, whispering in her ear.
Please behave, understand? I don't  know what we'll do if this doesn't  work, so behave, sweetheart. Behave,  behave.
As he exits towards his own apartment.
Matt is extraordinarily anxious. Then he HEARS loud cryin and screaming from next door. There is a stab of despair. Matt deflates, then resigned, exits.
The sound of screaming now louder. He walks to Lucy's doo takes a breath and knocks. The door opens and Lucy stands there looking rattled.
I'm sorry I bothered you. (calling inside) Jeannie...
Could I have her a little bit longer?  My little boy just fell and Jeannie  is the only one he let hold him.
A devil's weight lifted from his shoulders. The slap-happ smile of the just saved plastered on his face.
Your little boy fell, so he's  screaming. And you want her to stay.
Lucy, confused by his buoyant reaction, nods.
Okay. Seven dollars an hour?
Great. Thank you. See you later,  Jeannie.
He tries to kiss her, but she shuns him. Lucy, now having official status, turns to admonish her.
No, that's okay. I'm fine with it. I  feel fine.
Burke walks tight little circles near Cathy and the rest his staff while a few feet away Studio Executives stand i cluster. There is a DISTANT, RHYTHMIC SHUFFLING SOUND. Bu walks past Cathy.
Nothing good that happens tonight  can make it worth feeling the way I  do right now. Nothing. (turning to Cathy) What do you think?

(nervously taking the  plunge) To be honest, I had problems with  'Ground Zero.' But this 'People Get  Hurt' one, while it might not be my  exact, exact thing, I think will  really work for an audience. It's so  over the top, you have a great time.
So you think it'll score big?
Yes.
Where we discover the SOURCE OF THE SOUND. Some twenty ca counters on the floor riffling through stacks of cards wi erasers. Matt and Nan stand in the doorway.
Don't worry. My daughter used to  throw fits in supermarkets when we  first moved here. It's all so  perfectly normal. Plus I know a great  psychiatric children's group.
That's what breaks your heart.  Jeannie's problem is that she's so  down on herself.
Well, she's lucky to have a daddy  who cares, believe me.
I don't know if lucky's the word.  I'm hoping she's asleep when I get  home so I won't have to deal with  her... I'm actually afraid of my own  kid.

Oh, my. I've had exactly that feeling  and never said it out loud. See,  there are men who talk my language  and I'm just cursed that I'm not  attracted to them because they are  so nice they remind me of myself.
Matt laughs. In the b.g., the counting is completed.
Excellents?
Seven.
Very goods?
Fairs?
Poors?
Just a second... (finishes counting) 666.

The Group Captain notes the figure on a sheet, walks to t doorway and hands it to Nan, who is still deep into  conversation with Matt. She begins walking back to the th without looking at the sheet in her hand.
I felt terrible about the way I blew  up at you when I first met you. (before he can object) Please.
Burke and others waiting as Matt and Nan come to a stop s distance away.
What are they doing?

I began taking anti-depressants when  we moved here from Washington. I had  some small reactions--sleeping 14  hours, no libido, I gained 17 pounds  in nine days--that sort of thing. So  they gave me pills to deal with the  side effects. And then pills to deal  with the side effects I was getting  from those pills. All this besides  the stuff the nutritionist was giving  me. The combination formed some sort  of potion so that I keep telling the  truth. I don't have a choice. That's  why I was so rude to you.
Your doctor says this?

Oh, yes. He's excited, but only  because he sees glory for himself in  it... See, ordinarily I wouldn't say  that about my doctor, but I can't  help it, it's the truth. He's  monitoring me for a while longer  before writing it up for this medical  journal...
Cathy has joined them.
Burke's going crazy waiting for the  score.
Coming.
(to Matt) How are you, anyway?
Matt shifts, figuring out his answer.
(a small laugh) It's a tough one, huh? Me too.
Nan looks down at the score.
Oh, my. Matt, I'd better drive him  myself.
She starts for Burke.
As Nan arrives and hands the Studio Executives the score, Burke looking over their shoulders.
I can fix this... Get some narration  written. . . (turning to Director) You'll cut 30 minutes. It will come  out like butter.
We're only 77 minutes now...
(mumbling to himself) ...a 47-minute movie... no, that  won't work...
I have to go. I have a nanny problem.  Priorities, right?
Thanks for the support.
She kisses his cheek and leaves. A beat of silence... Bur turns to Nan.
(again) Can you help?
Exactly the moment Nan has been waiting for... she does h a valuable observation to offer at this dark moment.
Yes, I can.
(hopeful) Go ahead.
It's only a movie.
As Burke looks at her from the depths of his pain and see her confidently believing that she has imparted something value, the movie's marquee lights go off giving us a:

As he carries an enormously resistant Jeannie, wearing a  borrowed T-shirt nightie, back towards his apartment... M has Jeannie under one arm--her clothes and shoes in anoth Jeannie's arms are extended towards Lucy, who stands in t open doorway of her apartment. She begins thrashing. Gian tears come--the moment is operatic.
Let go. Please, Lucy, don't make me  go.
Everyone's tired. You can come back  tomorr...
Listen to me, Jeannie...
I want to live here with these people.  God, let me live here.
Maybe if she stayed tonight she...
I love it here so much that...
Now her father's last words have registered on her--she  immediately stops crying, though tears still roll down he cheeks.
Daddy says I can stay.
Jeannie wriggles away towards Lucy's doorway. Lucy takes  several steps toward Matt, who obviously fears the loomin exchange.
I no think you can give her what  pleases when she act like this...  Because then she think...
Matt is very much like a fighter taking a great deal of  punishment, knowing he is beaten, but being told by his c he must make a fight of it. He nods his head repeatedly i agreement...
I know... I know...
Now he sniffs the air in quick rhythm, hoping to draw in  some courage and resolve. He moves to Jeannie.
You'll see Lucy in the morning. We're  going home.
No. I'm not! STOP!
As they enter and Matt pushes her into the other room and closes the door, placing her in there alone.
Jeannie, behind the double glass-paneled doors of the bed
Matt, upset in a way he has never imagined, as he pops a  beer--puts on some headphones for calming music and begin to read a book on child behavior modification.

Feeling the restrictions of her punishment, pacing and no she begins to wail "THIS LONELY LIFE". Few adult women ha sung with such appropriate passion out of need and loss,  aloneness and confusion. The song finishes. Jeannie sits  huddled.

This rooftop serves as an outdoor commissary for Popcorn  Pictures. There are a few tables, snack machines and  umbrellas. The whole "D" staff is there, including Cathy, having lunch, along with Claire, the casting assistant. I the b.g., we see Matt, huddled, sitting on the roof's awf green outdoor carpeting, feeling much the same as Jeannie the previous scene.
Off in the distance, the Popcorn execs contentedly ply th trade. As he overhears their conversation and the words b to register in all their horror.
Will somebody take a minute to look  over my casting list before Burke  gets here?
