And now Burke and CAMERA meet up--the effect being that h is talking directly to us as he continues.

(again) We do have some kind of responsibility  to the audience... You just saw his  screentest... so, if this is the  first time you saw the guy, do you  come out thinking to yourself and  your girl friends, 'I'd sure go to  bed with him; oh God, would he be  something.' Would you, Cathy?... I'm  being real here.
No...
Okay, so let's keep looking.
They file out. Cathy gets up several beats later than the others... and follows them out, avoiding Nan's look.
She's been sitting here for quite a while... she can post no longer; she dials as one of her MOVIE SOUND TRACKS PLA in the background.
(into phone) Hello. Matt... Hi... Okay, sure...
She listens, waiting for him to quiet Jeannie.

(again) Matt... (louder) Matt... Matt... Maybe it would be  easier if I just said 'hi' to her...  Hi, Jeannie... Yes, it's exciting...  No, no. He's right, honey, they get  somebody to read it to you. Now, put  your dad on--it's important. No,  first put your dad on... DAMN IT! (she waits a beat) ...Matt. Uh-huh, a few hours ago...  They all... everyone liked your work,  but I think they'll go for a name or  something.

She listens to him. He is hurt. Cathy, though, is also  wrestling with her own internal struggles. She has betray him and is ashamed; in a strange way--terrified. She is,  therefore, just a little irritable.

(again) It's not a matter of doing it  differently... they liked what you  did, a lot... they laughed and...  it's not you... it's them. (suddenly her breath  comes weird) No, please. Don't thank me. If you  feel like getting together later or  anytime, call me, okay? You sound  like you have your hands full right  now... Goodbye.
As he hangs up...
I wanted to talk to her again...  I...

She stops in mid-sentence, looking at her father. He is  overcome... his energy failing to get him past this most  awful moment in his life. She moves to his side. He start to cry and, urgently seeking privacy, he moves quickly to the bathroom, rubbing Jeannie in an instinctive gesture o reassurance. He closes the door.
Devoid of anger. Sympathy so pure that it wrenches. She s to move towards the bathroom. Her voice sweet...
Dad? Daddy?
Matt opens the door quickly.
Everything's okay... I'm sorry I  forgot to put you back on with Cathy.
He walks across the room, Jeannie tracking him.
You didn't cried because of that...  I don't even want to talk to her.

Matt sits down, still suffering a bit of dysfunction, una to keep up appearances other than a few minor half-hearte tweaks at his daughter who stands solemn and silent at hi side. She pets him some... this goes on for several beats the STRAINS OF "YOU COULD BE WONDERFUL" accompany the mom Then:
(a whisper) Dad. Can I say just one thing?
With some effort, Matt lifts his head and nods permission
You've got to make me supper.
Matt nods, rises and leads her into the small kitchen.

Burke is wearing a T-shirt and shorts as he walks to his  four-stops-past-state-of-the-art Stairmaster and turns it while looking over his shoulder at the telephone... now  sucking in some courage, he goes to the phone and speed d He begins to climb the stairs.
You have reached the Warner's Hotline.  Estimated Box Office Grosses for  Friday, December 3rd, Weekend Number  49, are as follows in millions of  dollars.
He braces himself... there is a tone, then:
Due to the high volume of calls, we  must ask you to wait till a line is  clear...
MUSIC IN... At first from the speaker phone... Burke movi in time to "THERE IS A LONELY..." And now singing... As t lyric concludes and the instrumental comes in.
(again) Thanks for waiting. Weekend 49 grosses  follow in millions of dollars.  'Belligerence,' 714 theaters. Two- point-one-eight million, down 46  percent.
Burke smiles with pleasure... his steps becoming lighter, more fanciful.
(again) 'Best Girl,' 1,820 theaters, six- point-four million, up 24 percent.
(contemptuously) Cappuccino movies.
Opening this weekend, 'Double Dare  Two,' 1,870 theaters, fourteen-point- three million.
...and now his film, "Ground Zero," is coming up to bat.. as succor to the gods, he tries to make his dance gleeful anticipation.
(again) 'Ground Zero,' 2,110 theaters, no  million, point four thousand dollars.
Burke falls off his Stairmaster and, from his new positio finishes his song.
Matt is driving. Burke is seated alongside him, talking  without looking at him.

I'm going to pieces... (whispering) The picture was budgeted at 21 million  and I spent 49 so they were a little  mad at me to begin with. Now it  doesn't open even with an Arby's  Roast Beef tie-in... I mean, we only  averaged 300 dollars a theater...  they're going to think I'm Woody  Allen.
I don't think you have to worry about  that.
Thanks. But this is private. What  about the exit survey? Did we do  good with any group at all?
Now we HEAR Nan's voice on the speakerphone which Burke h been addressing all along.
I can't hear you, but--hi, Matt-- that was funny.
Hi.
'I don't think you have to worry  about that?'
She laughs delightedly. Burke leans across Matt's lap to closer to the microphone.
Did we do well with any group at  all?
Eleven-year-old boys in the South.
He sits stupified.
(again) Burke? Burke? Matt, is he...
I'll see you later. Goodbye.
But, hon...
He hits the "end" button. He slumps for a second, then:
I'm all alone... (pause) At least there's that.
As the car arrives outside Popcorn Pictures, we can SEE s child actors and their parents arriving at the sound stag next door.
Are you going to need me? The kids  are rehearsing and I'd like to take  a look.
Yeah, sure. I have to stay inside  during lunch hours now anyway--that's  when everybody returns my calls  because they're trying to miss me.
(amazed) Is that true?
(misinterpreting) Yeah. Thanks for the support.
A row of parents standing near their child actors, adjust them--not unlike handlers of racing Greyhounds.

Seen from a distance--her father behind her. In the  foreground, the mass of workers on the stage, It is, in  effect, her POV, even though she is in the extreme backgr of the shot. We MOVE CLOSER to Jeannie and her father--ev a bit behind them. Jeannie is scared.
I bet I know what it looks like to  you.
What?
A giant "find Waldo."
Despite herself, she smiles at the reference, though her  tone is a bit sarcastic.
Very funny.
Five minutes, children, then we need  you for work on the set.
Set?
That pretend living room, right over  there.
Okay. Set. Bye...
(holding her arm) Wait a second, Jeannie. Let Daddy  give you a few tips here.
(twisting away) Nooo. I've got to get to work.

She breaks free, depriving Matt of the sweet and simple m he wanted with her. She's one of the first ones on the se other kids still hugging their parents. As Cathy comes up behind Matt, we can HEAR Jeannie who, having so small a t for her father, needs to confirm what he just told her.
(faintly) Is this the set?
Matt reacts.
Parents to Room Two, please. (as he goes by Matt) Parents to Room Two, please.
Jeannie is watching.
(again) We have to clear the set.
Matt looks him off fiercely. The Passing Voice addresses friendlier parents.
(again) This way, parents.
I'm glad I found you.
Hi.
As they walk.
You holding up? What did you do last  night after I called?
(as if teasing) What do you think I did? I cried  like a baby.
Okay. Okay. So you don't want to  tell me. Be a tough guy.
Now you got it.
I feel relieved just seeing you after  all that stuff... whew... Okay. (preparing to go) Burke wants to...
You ever go out with him?
Cathy is as simple and direct as she is embarrassed.
Yes.
You slept with him?
Yes.
Did you hate it?
Eventually.
(reeling a bit) Good Lord.
This is the thing that makes me  nervous about you... You keep on  assuming I'm nicer than I am.
He kisses her. She kisses back. Then there is an  extraordinarily loud and piercing voice.
DAD!!
He turns to see Jeannie beckoning to him from the stage-- director, standing at her side, joins in. He walks to the
The Director is talking to Jeannie who seems, even from a distance, distraught and lost. She sees Matt.
There's such trouble.
She's very worried about being able  to pretend cry when she has to and  she doesn't get it about memorizing.  That's all.
(aghast) That's all?!?
The Director beckons Matt to lead her away. He does.
This isn't going to be good.
Not with that attitude.
She seems stung by this, unusually vulnerable. He changes tactics, softening.
(again) It's just that they... Well, did  they tell you what an audience is?
(insulted) I know what an audience is.

Good. Now, because there's an  audience, they want you to know all  the words you have to say really  well. And since you can't read yet... (off her fierce look) ...you're going to have to be patient  and try hard. I can help you.
She grasps at this unlikely straw.
Can you help me to cry?
Yes. (on her broad disbelief) I can. I can help make it okay. Trust  me.
Jeannie pauses half a beat, then:
I miss my mother bigger than you  know.
Matt on phone, Jeannie standing next to him reaching for phone.
(to Jeannie) Not yet. Don't grab. (into phone) Thank you. We really appreciate this.  Hi, Beth. I...
Jeannie grabs the phone in a flash.
(softly into phone) Mom? No... Nothing... Nothing...  Nothing. Nothing... Would you talk?  I'd just like to listen to you...  Wait. Let me sit down.

Jeannie sits herself by the window, protected by an iron  grill, and sits listening to her mother. There is about t pose something prescient; unmistakably, Jeannie will look this way again as a young woman cloaked in the love of so guy... but for now it's her mother, her crazy mother, who blots out dread. Matt is struck by how quiet and adoring  Jeannie looks even as he moves to give his daughter some  privacy. Several beats, Jeannie noticing her Dad looking her--switching positions, body language indicating that s wants to put him out of her mind... then a thought.
Dad says he's going to make me to  really cry.
Jeannie, your mom's not going to  understand what you mean.
Jeannie shushes him, resisting with surprising will and  strength when he tries to get the phone.

(to Matt) She understands!!! (into phone) He's being terrible right now. (faster; avoiding  Matt) I love, loved, the coloring book you  sent me. Goodbye. Wait. I love you.  Let me hang up first. Love you. Send  me a letter. Bye. And a beaded T- shirt. Bye.
She hangs up. Matt pissed.
Why don't you let me be on your side  for a second?
I can't even understand what you're  saying now.
Do you know what trust means?
Not very.
It means that even if something is  hard to believe, you believe someone  you trust because you know he wouldn't  say it unless it were true.
I understand. So I don't trust  anybody, right?
Yeah, I think you get the concept.
You don't make sense. I don't  understand you.
I think you do.
Jeannie reacts broadly... indicating what a difficult man she's stuck with.
Just know that...
Okayyyy!
(giving up) You want to help me make a phone  call?
She goes quickly to the phone and picks it up.
Seven... two...
(hitting numbers) Who are we calling?
Cathy. She's very nice. One... six...
(hard to read) "Very nice..." One...
As she answers phone.
Hi... (to Matt) What now?
Tell her, 'How are you' and then let me...
How are you?
Jeannie... I can't talk now because...
Wait, my dad wants to...
Tell him I can't talk 'cause I'm on  the phone with a director...
He wants to talk to you very much  and...
(sharply) I can't. I have to hang up.
She does.
Jeannie, truly stung by the hang-up. She takes this act o Cathy's as an insult to herself and her father. Matt does feel too wonderful about it himself.
You have to understand that sometimes  people are too busy.
So she's too busy for you?
Burke and Nan eating together on an elevated balcony  overlooking the main eating area.
We look like jerks eating here this  early. Everybody's going to think we  couldn't get a reservation for the  hot hours.
Why do you do this to yourself? Why  do you insist on eating dinner in a  restaurant where you're bound to see  all the people you're afraid of?
I'm not afraid of them.
What do you call it when you think  that what a group of people think of  you can confirm or destroy any decent  idea you have of yourself?
Normal.
How did little Jeannie do today?
Isn't it something that they have  you testing the TV show?
What I asked was, how did Jeannie  do?
What are you talking about?
Somebody else. Jeannie. How did she  do?
Don't talk to me like this.

(really pissed) I want to be treated as if I'm really  saying words to you which you engage  and respond to. I like Matt; I'd  like to know how his daughter did.  So before you take your dance of  desperation across the restaurant  and I end up feeling so sorry for  you that I could die, I would like  you to answer my question.
She did okay... and don't worry about  Matt... If the pilot sells, his kid  will be making five thousand a week.  So what do you know about 'People  Get Hurt?'
I'm told that they're not going to  release it...
I knew. I knew. What the hell are  you smiling for?
Forgive me. But telling you about  this latest failure of yours--it  pleases me. I have no idea why.
I can't be with someone who's not  rooting for me.
I think I am. It's just that rooting  for you is a good deal more  complicated than you realize. (as he rises) Don't go.
Don't worry. I'm not that mad. I  gotta do this.
MUSIC IN as Burke leaves the table. This "Dance of  Desperation" is classical. Burke himself lifting one of t women in greeting, then, as he puts her down.
(again) Sorry. I thought you were someone  else.
As he continues to go from table to table.
As she looks down on him, dying for him, we HEAR her sing the song "Poor Bastards". Finally, not only about Burke-- the other damaged souls he seeks to dance with. Now, Nan take no more. She exits.
As he sees her go past in the background, he goes after h finally grabbing her near the Maitre D' station. This, ju as TWO IMPORTANT COUPLES arrive. Burke frantically tries cover.
Nan, you know Victor and his wife... (he mumbles, unable  to remember any wife's  name) and Jay and his wife... (he mumbles)

Yes. I'm sorry I can't talk now. I'm  very upset about what's happening to  Burke, so I just made up my mind I  can't be witness to it anymore if I  love him and I certainly shouldn't  be here if I don't... so I was just  in the process of leaving when he  stopped me and you folks walked in...  I'm sure you've had something like  this happen to you some time... some  horrible thing in your personal life  happening in public.
They all nod and ad-lib agreements with her premise to Bu amazement.
(again) Thank you for understanding. (to Burke) Goodbye. I wish only good things for  you even though I feel I've been  really damaged by this relationship.
She exits, enormously upset. Burke, torn between followin her and repairing the social damage. But the couples are  paying him no mind; rather they are impressed with Nan. A they comment, i.e.
Wasn't that spectacular? I've never  seen anybody that secure...
Burke accepts the compliments as if meant for him.
Thank you. Thank you. We're very  close.
The strains of "Poor Bastards" underscoring the moment as Burke rushes into the parking area and grabs Nan's hand j as a valet brings her car.
You don't understand that I'm  exhausted from hurting. I'm through  with you.
She begins to cry. Ordinarily this would be a scene which would be unendurable for Burke. However, the lesson of a  moment ago is not lost on him. As people get out of cars witness the sobbing Nan.
(to restaurant patrons) Excuse me, we're working our shit  out... I'm sure it happened to you...  you know, private stuff in public.
The reaction to his openness is disdain and passing conte She drives off, leaving Burke hurt and alone. "Poor Basta up and out.
The lighting soft and sweet. Jeannie's words are tentativ as she talks to her father who sits watching intently.
I don't know if I've been bad. I  know somebody's been bad. (hopefully) ...maybe it's you.
Matt laughs. Jeannie looks at him shyly... he looks at he with encouragement. Suddenly she is in his arms, hugging hard, an emotional dam seems to have broken.
Oh, I love you so much, I love you  so much... I love you so much.
Matt holds on--clearly, deeply moved. Then he exercises t effort to control his emotions and speaks, surprisingly, a Black woman.
(as Black woman) I hope that makes you feel a whole  lot better, Chile... 'Cause it sure  goes a long way to cure what ails  me.
I can't believe I...
(as himself, coaching) ...got in this much...
...got in this much trouble. .
Right. Over a...
(guessing) Word?
Yes. 'I can't believe I got in this  much trouble over a word.' Now do  you know what she means when she  says that?
I don't want to talk about it--just  say her stuff so I know mine.
No.
She starts to flail a bit.
It's your choice... But I'm not  helping unless you try to understand  as well as memorize. It will be fun.  Come on. I know it's hard...
Okay. Okay...

Anything to shut me up, huh? Okay,  this little girl you're pretending  to be... she can't be with her Mommy  either, just like you, or her  father... she has to stay in Rainbow  House which is called that because... (Jeannie starts  fidgeting) Jeannie... (she stops) ...because everyone's a different  color... so when this little girl  calls the black lady who takes care  of all the children this terrible  word... it's like the worst thing  anybody can do... Come here.
(approaching him) I don't want to do the 'I love you'  again.
Yeah, I might have been working you  too hard on that one.
She is unable to resist muttering one sarcastic shot.
Yeah. Why don't you do that with  poopie Cathy?
(ignoring her) Now, did the director tell you how  he wanted you to do it?
He said to smile all the time almost  and to talk... uh...
Faster?
Yes.
Okay. We don't always get good  directors, so it's important for  us...
Me. You're not in the show.
I'm referring to the family of actors,  you little shithead.
Jeannie doesn't know quite how to take the name calling.  MUSIC IN... we're heading for a rendezvous with a dance a it CONTINUES ACROSS THE CUT TO:
Matt and Jeannie walking from the catering truck. They ar eating ravenously. MUSIC CONTINUES... VERY JOYOUS.
This is so good...
It's a breakfast burrito. It's what  actors eat when they're working.
(excited) Really.
Now, let's work a little more. The  most important acting you do is when  you listen. You're worried about  being able to cry when you're supposed  to, right?
Yes. So much.
Well, there are really only two ways  to do it. Think of something that  makes you really sad... or forget  you're you and really forget you're  pretending...
How do I do that one?
Matt reads from script.
(as a furious Black  woman) 'Don't test me, child! I could eat  you for lunch when I was your age  and I'm a hell of a lot bigger now!'
Jeannie looks afraid.

That's it... You just looked at me  and acted right without even thinking.  And there are games you can play to  help you with this. Get up... (she does) Now, be my mirror... do exactly what  I do... that's it... now, at a certain  point, I'm going to become your  mirror, but I'm not going to tell  you when... you tell me...
(hesitantly) Now?
Matt nods.
(enthusiastically) Okay. We're going to make up words.  The words aren't what matter now.
I'm on a roof...
You're a great dad.
You're a... (then stops; then  smiles at him)
This acting exercise of Chicago's Story Theater leads int the song, "BE MY MIRROR." As the song finishes, Matt and  Jeannie are in the best spirits we've seen as an A.D.  approaches.
They need you.
Okay.
She takes the A.D.'s hand as Matt calls.
You're welcome. Don't mention it.
Cathy is in mid conversation with Millie. Matt enters and boldly says his piece.
I'm a free man. Let's go to your  house and break the answering machine.
You know, I could get away now. But  I've got a big meeting later. We'd  better take two cars.
Millie, having been at the screen test viewing, is taken  aback, looking from one to the other. Cathy knows what sh thinking and is unnerved, feeling silently accused, as sh leads Matt out.
See you later. Thanks again.
Cathy's car followed by Matt in Burke's car. The frame ho both cars close as if this were one long car.
She seems troubled. Then a decision. She dials a number o her mobile phone and picks up the receiver.
The phone rings. He punches the speaker button.
I hope it's you.
Hi.
Matt waves...
(delighted) So this is how the big ones make  out.
Almost bumper to bumper... snuggling.
She takes a breath and then plunges.
As he hears one of the more ominous phrases of the motion picture community.
Matt, will you take me off the  speaker?
He picks up the phone. We intercut between the cars.
What's the matter?
(hyper) I don't know whether I'm being a  coward for telling you this way or  brave for telling you period... Can  you hear me?
Yes.
But I better talk fast because this  is where my phone always kicks out...  When we did your screentest... Can  you hear me?
Yes.
Well, I sort of folded on you at the  end.
She pauses, silence, then:
Matt?
You didn't like what I did?
I did. Truly. But the discussion got  sort of dumb. It was a question of  sexiness.
That's what it came down to?
Well, sort of, yes.
You folded on whether or not I'm  sexy. You don't think I'm sexy...  and you expressed that to...
Well, I'll tell you. I certainly  must think so pretty much because I  feel great about where we're going  now...
There is a longish line of cars behind Matt and Cathy.
Are you very mad at me?
No. You were just... Aw, damn it, I  am. Very. Yes.
Matt manages to pull to the side... the other cars gobbli the places behind Cathy, who sees this... and now she wat Matt's car recede from her view.
Cathy going out of sight.
As he lets her go.
He is in bed, wearing a bathrobe, watching projection TV.
...number seven at the box office  this week-end is...
He switches channels.
...the two words are Tom Cruise.
He switches channels.
...becoming the first lawyer to be  awarded his own star on Hollywood  Boule...
He turns off the TV and crosses to the phone, allowing us read the back of his bathrobe "ROCKY BALBOA."
He looks at the clock which reads "four a.m." and dials.
Hello, Nan. I hope it's not too late  to call.
She has been crying.
I'd like another chance.
You only think you feel that way  because you're on the verge of failure  and you're without a core...
See. Nobody else gets me. (a beat then) You wanna have a little sex, honey?
(a beat then) You know I've never hung up on anybody  in my life... because what if the  next thing they said solved  everything... but I must end this  conversation.
Nan hangs up. Burke picks up a pocket electronic notepad  from the bedstand and hits the scroll button.
Names and phone numbers.
He scrolls past numbers, considering, finding them wantin so that, finally, he is scrolling the emptiness of his  relationships. Now he considers one number and dials.
The phone rings. He picks it up.
Hello.
Hi, Matt, this is Burke. I'm sorry  to bother you at home, but you know  Nan... We were going out a little  and I could use another guy's slant  on what's just happened.
I don't think I can get into this...
Why? Did I catch you at a bad time?
Worse. You caught me at a bad time  you caused.
Oh, you mean about the screentest.  The whole room thought you did good  work.
(reinventing irony) Thanks.
Yeah, look, I'm not going to bother  you about my thing.
Yeah. Okay, good night.
As he hangs up. Looks down and turns off his phone number pocket computer. MUSIC RECALLS Prince's "There is Lonely.
MUSIC SEGUES to recall "I'LL DO ANYTHING," as he drives p the line waiting to see RAINBOW HOUSE.

We see Jeannie's face in the mirror, but it is seen throu something resembling fleece, which we now recognize as th strands of Jeannie's hair being combed out to the side by expert hair-dresser. Jeannie is shifting nervously in the large room where each chair is filled with a child of a  different age and color. In the b.g., we can HEAR the voi of the WARM-UP MAN.
...pilot for a new show called  'Rainbow House'. Just listen to our  band and I'll be back to tell you  more and make you love me...

The audience laughs thinly. The BAND PLAYS as someone clo the door to the make-up room muffling the offstage sound. There is a good deal of tension in the brightly lit room. Jeannie sits between a FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD HISPANIC BOY and FOUR-YEAR-OLD ASIAN GIRL. The room is abuzz... kids runni lines and loudly talking... this builds to a musical life in our first audition scene... there is a briefly sung ph (Jeannie not taking part).

The parents, in the same variety of skin colors as the ch actors, are stuffed into a small room being patronized by the ASSISTANT DIRECTOR. Matt is grimly seated in the midd of a long sofa containing stage mothers. Another sofa is feet away; the parents strain at each other. The A.D. is  talking grandly but we cannot hear his words because the  Rainbow Parents are SINGING a phrase from the same song w heard in the make-up room. Matt does not take part in the singing. The music goes under allowing us to now hear the A.D.'s words.
...and when you're in the audience,  make sure you laugh and applaud even  when it's somebody else's kid...
There is appreciative laughter from everyone save Matt, w rises in disgust and crosses out of the room.
(again) You're not allowed near the stage.  We only have a few minutes...
Matt ignores him and exits.

head_text.subj: MUSIC NOW EMPHASIZING THE TENSION OF THE PRE-SHOW ATMOSPH

text: Matt, moving about the area, looking for Jeannie, spots a cluster of other cast members excitedly awaiting their  introduction. Jeannie not among them. An A.D. talks with  concern to a P.A.
Let me know if you see the little  white girl.
Matt, growing concerned, walks on, then:

Across the stage to the distant make-up room. Jeannie, al in the room, which is so brightly lit it creates a bizarr effect, as if she were under a surreal spotlight. MUSIC  reprises Jeannie's Sinead O'Connor song, "Lonely Life of  Mine."
Stopping his impulse to go to her--he continues to observ

Jeannie is nervous and uncertain... She plays with the ha of the make-up chair... turns herself back and forth... T a very attractive TEN-YEAR-OLD BOY enters the scene--obvi telling her to hustle... He offers his hand and she takes it, instinctively masking all clues that this hand holdin is a "first" of great moment in her life. As they move to the main stage area, Jeannie looks around, needing  something... her dad.
Jeannie.
She turns--sees her father and gives a small, cursory nod He moves quickly, drawing even with her but still giving a bit of space and a low-key pep talk.
Just remember. You're not even here  tonight. There's only this other  little girl that you're pretending  to be who lives at Rainbow House.
...and who just vomited.
Matt breaks up. Even Jeannie smiles briefly, then she tak him aside for privacy.
I just found out that we bow before  we even do anything.
Great.
And everybody claps.
Great.
I made up a great bow. You going to  look?
Wouldn't miss it.
I'm not going to be able to cry.  It's too hard for me.
Hey, then they'll just give you more  chances after everyone leaves.
This does not satisfy her. She rolls her eyes as she is p away towards the front of the stage. Matt watches as the year-old veteran actor leads his little daughter towards debut.

MUSIC, a tension-filled version of "Poor Bastard." Burke' stride was never stronger, his posture never worse; head  hunched down into his neck. Suddenly, he reacts as he see the staff of Popcorn Pictures grouped together backstage. Cathy walking towards the group hurriedly from one direct as Burke approaches from the other. Seeing his staff has  clearly moved Burke.

Look at you. You're all here because  of what's on the line for me tonight.  Having this many people in your corner  helps more than I would have ever  guessed. I'm just very grateful that  I made you come.
He starts off, but a jubilant Cathy stops him, whispers  something. He reacts with excitement.
She sees Matt deep in the wings watching the stage. She c to him with some urgency.
Matt. Matt. Matt.
He turns and she beckons him towards her. With some hesit he joins her.
I don't want to miss her introduction.
I'll talk fast. It's amazing news.  Oliver Stone's been looking for a  comedy and...
